measured_by: single-item perceived danger of driving after 3 drinks Likert scale
justification: “Participants reported on their baseline attitudes toward driving after drinking with a single item, ‘How dangerous do you think it is to drive within 2 hours after having 3 drinks?’ … rated … on a Likert scale from 1… to 4.”

measured_by: self-reported frequency of driving after ≥3 drinks in past 3 months and 1 year
justification: “Participants reported the number of times they had driven in the past 3 months and 1 year after consuming 3 or more drinks within a 2 hour period.”
“Breath Alcohol Concentration (BrAC). An FST-Alco-Sensor breathalyzer … was used to assess BrAC.”

measured_by: visual analogue scale slider ‘How intoxicated do you feel right now?’
justification: “Participants reported on their levels of subjective intoxication with a single item, ‘How intoxicated do you feel right now?’ Participants responded using a slider bar on a visual analogue scale (VAS) from 0… to 100…”

measured_by: VAS slider ‘How dangerous do you feel it is for you to drive right now?’
justification: “Participants reported on how dangerous they perceived it would be for them to drive with a single item, ‘How dangerous do you feel it is for you to drive right now?’ Participants responded using a slider bar on a VAS from 0… to 100…”
“Participants reported on their willingness to drive with three items assessing, ‘Would you drive a distance of __ mile(s) right now?’… responses… yes/no for 1, 3, and 10 miles.”

measured_by: Intoxicated Driving Decision Making Task (hypothetical drink-cost scenarios)
justification: “Intoxicated Driving Decision Making Task… scenarios systematically varied drinks and ride costs… Participants chose whether to drive or seek a ride… Bayesian cognitive modeling was used to identify the strategy individuals used to make their decisions on the task.”
